trans-unit.source: Represents a link within a syndication feed or item.
<xref:System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink> can be added to a <xref:System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationFeed> or <xref:System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationItem>.

When serialized to Atom 1.0 a <xref:System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink> is written out as a `<link>` element, with the <xref:System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink> properties written out as attributes of the `<link>` element.
When serialized to RSS 2.0, the first <xref:System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink> with a relationship value of ‘alternate’ is written out as a `<link>` element.
Any additional links are written out as a `<a10:link>` elements.
Creates a new instance of the <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink"></xref> instance.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink"></xref> class with the specified instance.
The <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink"></xref> instance used to initialize the new instance.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink"></xref> class with the specified <xref href="System.Uri"></xref>.
The URI to the linked resource.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink"></xref> class with the specified <xref href="System.Uri"></xref>, relation type, title, media type, and length.
Well-known relationship types include:
`alternate` - The link identifies an alternate version of the resource described by the containing Feed or Item.
`related` - The link identifies a resource related to the containing Feed or Item.
`self` - The link identifies a resource equivalent to the containing Feed or Item.
`enclosure` - The link identifies a related resource that is potentially large in size and might require special handling.
This link relation is often used when podcasts or audio files are distributed in a Feed.
`via` - The link identifies a resource that is the source of the information provided in the containing Feed or Item.
The URI to the linked resource.
The relationship type.
The title of the link.
The media type of the link.
The length of the linked content.
Gets the attribute extensions of the link.
<xref:System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink.AttributeExtensions%2A> allows you to add custom attributes to the <xref:System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink>.
When serialized to Atom 1.0, the custom attributes appear within the `<link>` element.
When serialized to RSS 2.0, the custom attributes appear in the `<a10:link>` element.
Any valid XML attribute can be added.
A dictionary that contains a collection of attribute extensions.
Gets and sets the base URI of the syndication link.
A <xref href="System.Uri"></xref> instance that contains the base URI of the syndication link.
Creates a copy of the current <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink"></xref> instance.
A new <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink"></xref> instance.
Creates a new <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink"></xref> object with the specified <xref href="System.Uri"></xref>.
The URI of the linked resource.
A new <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink"></xref> instance.
Creates a new <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink"></xref> object with the specified <xref href="System.Uri"></xref> and media type.
The URI of the linked resource.
The media type of the link.
A new <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink"></xref> instance.
Creates a media enclosure link with the specified URI, media type, and length.
This method creates a new <xref:System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink> object and sets <xref:System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink.RelationshipType%2A> to `enclosure`.
The URI of the linked resource.
The media type of the link.
The length of the linked content.
A new <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink"></xref> instance.
Creates a new <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink"></xref> with the specified URI, media type, and relationship type set to `self`.
The URI to the linked resource.
The media type of the link.
A <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink"></xref> instance.
Creates a new <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink"></xref> with the specified URI and relationship type set to `self`.
The URI to the linked resource.
A <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink"></xref> instance.
Gets the element extensions for the <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink"></xref>.
Element extensions are valid XML elements that are not specified in either the Atom 1.0 or RSS 2.0 specifications.
You can add any valid XML element as an extension, provided its namespace is different from the enclosing namespace.

A <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationElementExtensionCollection"></xref> that contains the element extensions for the <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink"></xref>.
Gets the absolute URI for the <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink"></xref>.
A <xref href="System.Uri"></xref> instance that contains the absolute URI of the <xref href="System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink"></xref>.
Gets and sets the length of the linked resource in bytes.
When serialized to Atom 1.0 the <xref:System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink.Length%2A> property is written as a `length` attribute in the `<link>` element.
When serialized to RSS 2.0 this value is written as the `length` attribute of the `<a10:link>` element.
The length of the linked resource.
Gets and sets the media type of the linked resource.
When serialized to Atom 1.0 this value is written as a `type` attribute in the `<link>` element.
When serialized to RSS 2.0 this value is written as the `type` attribute in the `<a10:link>` element.
The media type of the linked resource.
Gets and sets the relationship type of the linked resource.
Well-known relationship types include:
`alternate` - The link identifies an alternate version of the resource described by the containing Feed or Item.
`related` - The link identifies a resource related to the containing Feed or Item.
`self` - The link identifies a resource equivalent to the containing Feed or Item.
`enclosure` - The link identifies a related resource that is potentially large in size and might require special handling.
This link relation is often used when podcasts or audio files are distributed in a Feed.
`via` - The link identifies a resource that is the source of the information provided in the containing Feed or Item.
When serialized to Atom 1.0 this value is written out as the `rel` attribute of the `<link>` element.
When serialized to RSS 2.0, this value is written out as the `rel` attribute in the `<a10:link>` element.
The relationship type of the linked resource.
Gets and sets the title of the linked resource.
When serialized to Atom 1.0 this value is written out as the `title` attribute in the `<link>` element.
When serialized to RSS 2.0 the title is written out as the `title` attribute in the `<a10:link>` element.
The title of the linked resource.
Attempts to parse an attribute extension.
Attribute extensions are custom attributes that are not defined by the Atom 1.0 or RSS 2.0 specifications.
They are serialized as an attribute of the `<link`> element.
This method is an extension point that allows you to handle the deserialization of a custom attribute extension.
To do this, you must derive a class from <xref:System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink> and override this method.
This method is called for all unrecognized attribute extensions.
The name of the element.
The namespace of the element.
The attribute to parse.
The syndication version to use when parsing.
A value that specifies whether the attribute extension was parsed successfully.
Invalid XML encountered during read.
Attempts to parse an element extension.
Element extensions are valid XML elements that are not specified in either the Atom 1.0 or RSS 2.0 specifications.
You can add any valid XML element as an extension, provided its namespace is different from the enclosing namespace.
This method is an extension point that allows you to handle the deserialization of a custom element extension.
To do this, you must derive a class from <xref:System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink> and override this method.
This method is called for all unrecognized element extensions.
The <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref> to read from.
The syndication version to use while parsing.
A value that specifies whether the element extension was parsed successfully.
Invalid XML encountered during read.
Gets and sets the URI for the linked resource.
When serialized to Atom 1.0 this value is written out as the `href` attribute in the `<link>` element.
When serialized to RSS 2.0, this value is written out as the `href` attribute in the `<a10:link>` element.
A <xref href="System.Uri"></xref> instance that contains the URI for the linked resource.
Writes the attribute extensions to the specified <xref href="System.Xml.XmlWriter"></xref> using the specified syndication version.
Attribute extensions are custom attributes that are not defined by the Atom 1.0 or RSS 2.0 specifications.
They are serialized as an attribute of the `<link>` element.
This method is an extension point that allows you to handle the serialization of custom attribute extensions.
To do this, you must derive a class from <xref:System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink> and override this method.
This method is called for all unrecognized attribute extensions.
The <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref> to write to.
The syndication version to use while writing.
Writes the element extensions to the specified <xref href="System.Xml.XmlWriter"></xref> using the specified syndication version.
Element extensions are valid XML elements that are not specified in either the Atom 1.0 or RSS 2.0 specifications.
You can add any valid XML element as an extension, provided its namespace is different from the enclosing namespace.
This method is an extension point that allows you to handle the serialization of custom element extensions.
To do this, you must derive a class from <xref:System.ServiceModel.Syndication.SyndicationLink> and override this method.
This method is called for all unrecognized element extensions.
The <xref href="System.Xml.XmlReader"></xref> to write to.
The syndication version to use while writing.
